critique: This document is an executive order from 1940 that allows specific appointments within the Welfare Unit of the Public Buildings Administration, Federal Works Agency, without adhering to the usual competitive requirements of the Civil Service Rules. The order is recommended by the Federal Works Administrator and concurred in by the Civil Service Commission. There is no clear indication of ideological tilt, immigration approach, or impact on national security vs. civil liberties. The order seems to expand executive power by bypassing standard hiring procedures, and it centralizes authority at the federal level by dictating appointments within a federal agency. There's a slight intervention in economic regulation by influencing employment within the agency. The social inclusion aspect is neutral, as the document doesn't explicitly promote or hinder diversity.
